key_points: An exclusive USA TODAY/Ipsos snap poll found 71% of Americans approved the guilty verdict in Derek Chauvin's murder trial.
The poll showed bipartisan agreement with 85% of Democrats, 55% of Republicans, and 71% of independents concurring with the verdict.
Chauvin was convicted of second- and third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in George Floyd's death.
Cliff Young, president at Ipsos, highlighted a rare moment of bipartisan consensus on the crime but noted partisan differences in perceptions of the events.
62% of polled Americans would accept the verdict and not engage in further protests or rallies.
54% of respondents prioritize law and order, even if it limits peaceful protests, showing sharp differences in views around law and order.
Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison and President Joe Biden called for significant changes and reforms in policing following the verdict.
President Biden advocated for the Senate's passage of the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act for increased police accountability.
Participants had mixed views on the nature of Floyd's death, with 40% describing it as murder and others seeing it as negligence or an accident.
The poll was conducted among 1,000 American adults and reported a confidence interval of 3.2 percentage points.
spokespersons: Joe Biden (President of the United States)
